title: Mattis Says He Was Frank With Trump but Never Blocked His Wishes
text:
Former Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said he was “right up front” in frank policy discussions with President Trump, but never blocked or delayed actions the president wanted him to take.

“I read at times that I was blocking or slow-rolling things that President Trump wanted,” Mr. Mattis said in an interview on “The Journal” podcast that airs Tuesday. “That’s not the way I deal with things. I’m from the West. Out here, we ride for the brand.”

He added that he and the president had lunch or a private Oval Office meeting every week both were in Washington, and “we had very open discussions.”

Mr. Mattis, a former four-star Marine general, spoke as his new book, “Call Sign Chaos,” was about to be released. Until now, he has remained largely silent about his time in the administration, which he joined at its outset in 2017, as well as his decision in December 2018 to resign. He quit in part because of a disagreement with Mr. Trump about the president’s desire to pull all American troops out of Syria, but also, as he made clear in a resignation letter, over ongoing disagreements about Mr. Trump’s criticism of America’s allies.

While Mr. Mattis was at the Pentagon, some Trump allies thought he slowed or blocked some of the actions the president wanted to take, including sending American soldiers to the Mexican border, withdrawing troops from Afghanistan and implementing a ban on transgender soldiers in the military.

Without discussing specific examples, Mr. Mattis denied trying to deflect the president’s order. Instead, he said his approach was to “go in, do your best, give straight-up advice.” In his book, he writes that he resigned when his “concrete solutions and strategic advice, especially keeping faith with our allies, no longer resonated.”

Mr. Mattis declined to discuss his specific assessments of Mr. Trump or his administration: “I owe them a time of silence,” he said. “They’re dealing with very, very difficult issues.” Later, he added: “So while I’ll talk about strategic issues, I’m not here to speak ill of a sitting president.”

He was frank, however, in discussing some of America’s security challenges, and the political system that confronts them.

He had, for example, harsh words for Russia and its behavior. He noted that after the end of the Cold War, while a Marine commander, he participated in training for joint peacekeeping missions with Russian troops. “Those days are long gone,” he said. “Russia with its invasion of Georgia, invasion of the Ukraine, has proven to be an authoritarian state that wants a veto authority over the nations along its periphery.”

Of China, he said: “It’s not feasible for us to say that they would be authoritarians at home and somehow internationally they would be respectful of other people. You can’t square that circle.”

He also was critical of President Obama’s attempt to withdraw American troops from Iraq, which he described as an example of “poor strategic decision-making.” Mr. Mattis was in command of U.S. troops in the region at the time.

Mr. Obama “understandably wanted to end that war,” he said, but acted “against military advice, against the intelligence community’s advice. My point is that you may want a war over, you may even declare a war over, but the bottom line is the enemy gets a vote. And instead of ending that war, we in effect restarted it when we pulled our troops out of Iraq.”

While Defense secretary, Mr. Mattis also argued for keeping a robust American troop presence in Afghanistan, and he declined to estimate how long he thinks U.S. forces will need to remain in that country. The Trump administration is trying now to broker peace talks between the Afghan government and the Islamist forces of the Taliban movement.

But he said that terrorism will continue to be a threat until its “root causes” are eliminated. “This is simply something we’re going to have to accept, as unpalatable as that is. It’s going to take a while.”

While at the Pentagon, Mr. Mattis was part of an unusual governing alignment in which former generals held top civilian government posts; besides Mr. Mattis, John Kelly served as both secretary of Homeland Security and White House chief of staff, and H.R. McMaster as national security adviser. Mr. Mattis didn’t venture a judgment on how that experiment worked out: “I think that is something history will have to judge.”

Write to Gerald F. Seib at jerry.seib@wsj.com
description: Former Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said he was ‘right up front’ in policy discussions with President Trump, but never blocked or delayed actions the president wanted him to take.
